After hearing from constituents who were frustrated at not having the same access to their own credit score as their lenders had, I added language to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act that required the CFPB to investigate. As a result of my legislation, the CFPB found that consumers were in fact receiving different credit scores than lenders.  Building on this investigation, the CFPB announced last week that Equifax and Transunion were guilty of deceiving consumers and violating the protections I fought to include in Dodd-Frank.  The CFPB is requiring the two credit bureaus to give $17.6 million back to consumers who were harmed. These companies misled consumers about the value of the credit scores they sold: In their advertising, TransUnion and Equifax falsely represented that the credit scores they marketed and provided to consumers were the same scores lenders typically use to make credit decisions. In fact, the scores sold by TransUnion and Equifax were not typically used by lenders to make those decisions. This is a win for consumers and will level the playing field for anyone trying to make decisions about the amount of credit they can access and the interest rate they receive on their mortgages, car loans, college loans, etc. I am also a cosponsor of the Fair Access to Credit Scores Act, introduced earlier today, to provide consumers with an annual free credit score that is reliable and used by lenders. http://www.consumerfinance.gov/about-us/newsroom/cfpb-orders-transunion-and-equifax-pay-deceiving-consumers-marketing-credit-scores-and-credit-products/

I posted this Myth vs Fact on my Facebook page back in 2013 – given the current situation, in which the GOP is ACTUALLY trying to push their misguided health care plan forward WITHOUT a sense of the cost, I thought re-posting this would be appropriate:  MYTH: The Affordable Care Act is thousands of pages long, and was rammed through Congress without really being read and considered. FACT: The 906-page Affordable Care Act was passed by both houses of Congress, including a 60-vote majority in the Senate, and signed by the President after more than a year of debate, consideration by five separate House and Senate committees, a record 25 straight days on the Senate floor, and the inclusion of hundreds of amendments from both sides of the aisle. But don't take my word for it. Today’s Women’s History Month 3D Thursday spotlight is on the women of the Bread & Roses Strike. In 1912, the Massachusetts legislature passed a law reducing the workweek for women and children from 56 hours a week to 54. Women working in the Lawrence mills celebrated this progress – until mill owners cut their wages in proportion to the decreased hours. Already angry about the dangerous and appalling working conditions they were subjected to, the undermining of this new law propelled nearly 30,000 textile workers to walk off their jobs and to the streets to strike. Despite brutal opposition from mill owners and law enforcement in an attempt to dissuade the workers’ efforts, the Bread and Roses Strike was a success. This #3DThursday we honor the women at the front of this movement; women who were willing to risk their jobs and their safety to lead the fight for justice in the workplace. http://www.history.com/news/the-strike-that-shook-america-100-years-ago

This bill is key to that mission, and would be a powerful tool for eliminating synthetic opioids, like fentanyl, from the equation. I thank Rep. Fitzpatrick for his partnership to introduce the INTERDICT Act in the House, and I commend our Senate counterparts -  Senator Edward J. Markey, Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL), U.S. Senator Sherrod Brown (D-OH) and Senator Shelley Moore Capito (R-WV) - for their bipartisan leadership in this effort. For many undocumented immigrant children, the United States is the only country they have ever known. They were brought to the United States as children, through no fault of their own and yet the vast majority have grown or are growing into valued, productive members of our communities.  The DACA program, established in June, 2012, allowed some of these individuals who were brought to the United States as children, without legal status, to be considered for relief from deportation.  This program has been essential in bringing these individuals out of the shadows and helping them to contribute to our society in a gainful and legal way. DACA has also been key to better directing immigration resources towards preventing criminals from entering this country. It has been an important program for our national economy, national security and our national values. The Trump Administration’s misguided and cruel decision to eliminate #DACA puts that all in jeopardy and does nothing to fix our country’s broken immigration system. True immigration reform, which we need, will require bipartisan cooperation, not partisan politics and a White House that would punish children for the actions of their parents. I will continue to work with my colleagues in the coming months to support the DACA program with the hope that Congress will lead where the White House will not.
